Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Downdrag Behavior of Piles & Drilled Shafts After Liquefaction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Earthquake shaking can cause loose sands below the water table to liquefy and behave like heavy liquid, causing buildings, bridges and ports supported on shallow foundations to settle, slide or tip over. Direct and indirect economic losses resulting from liquefaction are substantial costs to society. One solution to this problem is to use deep foundations which penetrate through the liquefiable sand into a dense layer that doesn't liquefy. However, settlement of the liquefied sand can still cause downward friction on the foundation wall, increasing the load and leading to excessive settlement. In the absence of field measurements, engineers are uncertain about the amount of downward friction that will develop and how much settlement will occur. Because of this uncertainty contradictory design procedures are used. To remedy this problem, small explosive charges will be used to produce liquefaction under full-scale conditions and measurements will be made of the downward friction and foundation settlement. Tests will be performed on six different foundations at a site in Arkansas. Primary funding will be provided by the Arkansas State Highway and Transportation Department; however, supplemental funding from NSF will significantly expand the scope of the project. The results from these tests will allow engineers to evaluate the accuracy of existing design procedures and develop modifications to produce better agreement with measured behavior. Improved design procedures will allow engineers to design safe, yet cost effective foundation solutions which will remain stable during earthquakes.

To improve our understanding of liquefaction-induced downdrag on deep foundations, blast induced liquefaction tests will be performed on three full-scale drilled shafts and three driven piles (steel pipe, H sections, and pre-stressed concrete) at a site in Arkansas. NSF funding will be used to provide the static load that will be applied to each test foundation to simulate dead load while soil settlement and pile settlement will be measured after liquefaction. The objective is to measure negative skin friction and downdrag induced settlement. With the inclusion of a static load, the results from these tests will allow researchers to evaluate the accuracy of existing design recommendations and develop modifications to produce better agreement with measured response. Because deep foundations are a common approach for supporting structures in liquefiable sands, reliable design approaches are critical to provide cost effective foundations that are safe in future earthquakes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earthquake shaking can cause loose sands below the water table to liquefy and behave like heavy liquid, causing buildings, bridges and ports supported on shallow foundations to settle, slide or tip over.  Direct and indirect economic losses resulting from liquefaction are substantial costs to society.  One solution to this problem is to use deep foundations which penetrate through the liquefiable sand into a dense layer that doesn?t liquefy.  However, settlement of the liquefied sand can still cause downward friction on the foundation wall, increasing the load and leading to excessive settlement.  In the absence of field measurements, engineers are uncertain about the amount of downward friction that will develop and how much settlement will occur.  Because of this uncertainty contradictory design procedures are used. 

 

To help resolve these problems, we used small explosive charges to produce liquefaction under full-scale conditions in the field and measured downward friction and foundation settlement.  We performed test on six different foundations at a freeway interchange in Arkansas. Primary funding was provided by the Arkansas State Highway and Transportation Department; however, supplemental funding from the National Science Foundation expanded the scope of the project.  We performed tests on three concrete shafts that were four feet and six feet in diameter and extended 80 feet deep into the ground.  We also performed tests on three driven pile foundations consisting of round pipe, a steel H-section, and a pre-stressed concrete pile extending 70 to 85 feet below ground.  Prior to each test, we applied load to the test foundations using steel beams to simulate the weight of a structure.  Then after blasting, we measured the location of the liquefied layer, the settlement of the ground, the settlement of the pile, and the frictional forces on the pile.

 

The results of these tests showed that downward friction did develop after liquefaction.  The downward friction was about the same as the upward friction prior to liquefaction in soils that did not liquefy.  However, in the sands that liquefied, the downward friction was 40 to 50% of the original upward friction force. These results are consistent with results from similar tests conducted in Canada and Italy, and indicate that these friction forces would be appropriate for design applications.  Even after liquefaction-induced downward friction produced by ground settlement, most of the deep foundations themselves experienced relatively small and acceptable settlements when the bottom of the foundation provided significant support. This results points to the need to locate the bottom of the foundation in competent soils and to know how resistance develops with settlement at the base of the foundation.  This study also determined that the ?Neutral-Plane Method? provided a reasonable procedure for predicting the settlement of the pile is situations such as this contrary to some design approaches. 

 

The results from these tests will allow engineers to evaluate the accuracy of existing design procedures and develop modifications to produce better agreement with measured behavior. Improved design procedures will allow engineers to design safe, yet cost effective foundation solutions that will remain stable during earthquakes. The results from this study and other similar studies have prompted the National Academy of Engineering to investigate revisions of the bridge design codes that govern the calculation of downward skin friction during earthquakes.  In addition, this study provided support for one Ph.D. student and one MS student to gain experience with field testing procedures and complete their degrees.  Both students are now employed as professional engineers.
